title: Require Card ref permissions to use Card reference template tag in native query
body:
In English that means that in order to run a query like

```sql
SELECT * FROM {{card}}
```

where `{{card}}` is a `:card` template tag whose value is some Card (e.g. Saved Question) ID, you should need not only the usual native query data permissions but also permissions to view the Card in question, e.g. if the value of `{{card}}` is Card ID `1` then to run the query you should need read permissions for Card 1. Currently read permissions for a Card is just read permissions for the Collection it lives in.

This was accomplished by having parameter expansion add `:metabase.models.query.permissions/referenced-card-ids` keys to native queries when their parameters are expanded, and updating the required-query-permissions code to look for this key and add it to the set of required permissions.
author: camsaul
labels: [('backport', 'Automatically create PR on current release branch on merge')]

title: Remove field refs from DatasetEditor
body:
Depends on https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/45109
Related https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/42203
Related https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/25885
Related https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/33959
Related https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/36364

An attempt to simplify things by making metadata editing unaware of field refs. If this gets merged, we would rely on unique `column.name`. The PR doesn't fix anything on its own now.

Basically:
- `metadataDiff` becomes the single source of truth
- we use `column.name` for keys in `metadataDiff` and not field refs (which are not unique)
- we no longer change `result_metadata` in the current card before actually saving it
- we no longer try to make `metadataDiff` in sync with `result_metadata`. Instead, `metadataDiff` is applied on top of `result_metadata` in a selector. This was already the case, but because previously this code updated `result_metadata` at the same time, it had to deal with sync issues.
author: ranquild

title: Fix #35954: SQL-converted question with field filter breaks filtered dashboard if reverted back to its editor version
body:
This PR originally only reproduced #35954, but then @ranquild did his magic and actually fixed the root cause, so now the PR resolves #35954.

We've added quite involved E2E reproduction that also checks for the public sharing and the embedding scenarios.
It tests for a lot of permutations and tries to cover some edge cases.

title: Feature/28144 override download row limit for csv
body:
Partially implements https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/28144

### Description

I created the MB_ROW_LIMIT_CSV setting and used it in the determine-query-max-rows function.

### How to verify

1. set environment variable: MB_ROW_LIMIT_CSV=X
2. export csv file

### Checklist

- [x] Tests have been added/updated to cover changes in this PR

title: Allow ad-hoc release-notes generation
body:
Adds local scripting and a github action to generate release notes from any milestone

locally, if you have environment variables set up you can just go to the release directory and:

```sh
yarn generate-changelog v0.50.9 > changelog.log
```

or, in CI, you can just trigger a workflow dispatch and get a snapshot of "if we released this version right now, what would the release notes generate?"

[successful test run on this branch](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/actions/runs/9745811686)
author: iethree
labels: [('.Building & Releasing', ''), ('no-backport', 'Do not backport this PR to any branch'), ('.Team/DevEx', '')]

title: Create new release note sections
body:
### Description

Creates two new release-notes sections:
- Already Fixed
- Under the Hood

Under the hood issues take highest priority, they are any issue in a milestone with these labels:
- Type:Documentation
- .Ci & Tests
- .Building & Releasing

Already Fixed Issues will also not show up in the bug fix section even if they also have a bug fix tag.

### Checklist

- [x] Tests have been added/updated to cover changes in this PR
author: iethree
labels: [('.Building & Releasing', ''), ('no-backport', 'Do not backport this PR to any branch'), ('.Team/DevEx', '')]

title: Consolidate admin E2E reproductions for the release-x.50.x

- Almost a completely clean cherry-pick of [d7bd560](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/commit/d7bd5603bc16f287c71ff6f9299457bdf1b8abdc) (#43853.)

Had to revert React 18 and Metrics v2 changes.

- Clean cherry-pick of [44427fb](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/commit/44427fb61df5aca633d2a2aa0103457f10a656c2) (#44882)


> [!Important]
> We have a weird situation here because metrics v2 are implemented in `master`, and all related specs have been removed. They still exist in the release branch as a separate spec `e2e/test/scenarios/admin/datamodel/metrics.cy.spec.js`. I didn't move them to the `e2e/test/scenarios/admin/datamodel/datamodel.cy.spec.js` to prevent future merge-conflicts. I also [moved the only remaining metric v1 reproduction to the metrics spec](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/44963/commits/67e4e6eb28aaaceec1da44387960d86e2cd45996).

title: Milestone tracing logic update
body:
### Description

Our milestone-tracing logic was a little over-eager in detecting PR numbers from commit messages.

For example, a PR that [backported a bunch of changes mentioning a bunch of PRs](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/actions/runs/9694690637/job/26752868314#step:4:30) created some unintended messages.

The basic logic for tracing a release-branch commit back to an issue is:

- get all pr numbers from commit message in release branch, and fetch those PRs
- if its a backport pr, find the source PR from the pr body
- if its a source PR, find any issues closed in the PR body

I think the safer assumption is that we should only trace PRs mentioned in the first line of a commit message - other pr mentions should be informational

### Checklist

- [x] Tests have been added/updated to cover changes in this PR
author: iethree
labels: [('.CI & Tests', ''), ('no-backport', 'Do not backport this PR to any branch'), ('.Team/DevEx', '')]

title: [notification] New method: `channel/can-connect?`
body:
Part of milestone 2.1 of https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/43822
This PR does 2 things:
- add a new `channel/can-connect?` multimethod and implement for http
- the `channel/send!` method now has the first arg is a map with a `:type` key.

This is needed so that we can introduce a new entity: `channel`.

title: Repro parameter field matching issues for questions based on sql models
body:
Fixes the FE part of https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/42829
Fix walkthrough https://www.loom.com/share/e731f5b38bea48809dc65d6551853cfc

The fix doesn't work for embedded or public dashboards because of `param_fields` not populated on the BE.

How to verify:
- New -> Model -> SQL -> `SELECT * FROM PRODUCTS` -> Run -> Save
- Edit metadata -> Select `CATEGORY` -> Set to `Products.Category` -> Save
- New -> Question -> Models -> Select this model, Summarize -> Number of distinct values -> `State`
- Add this question to a dashboard
- Filter -> Location -> Map this filter to `State` -> Save dashboard
- Click on the filter widget. You should see the field values (state short names)
- Make this dashboard public and open the filter widget
- See that there is a plain text input because there is a bug on the BE.
author: ranquild
labels: [('backport', 'Automatically create PR on current release branch on merge'), ('.Team/Querying', '')]

title: Memoize driver.u/supports? only in prod
body:
Follows up on https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/44719 

This PR disables the memoization of `driver.u/supports?` in dev+test modes because the risk of creating accidental coupling between tests is high, and debugging test failures is too difficult to justify not .

It does add a difference in behaviour between production and dev+test modes, but I can't see much risk with this. Accidentally assuming driver.u/supports? is not memoized in prod when it actually is memoized is unlikely to lead to any incorrect tests. However, the reverse is not true: not recognising that driver.u/supports? is memoized in tests can lead to incorrectly passing tests and test failures that are hard to debug.
author: calherries
labels: [('backport', 'Automatically create PR on current release branch on merge'), ('.Team/Workflows', 'aka BEC')]

title: Revert: Fix appends for long column names
body:
This reverts https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/44727.

Introducing the buffer was a breaking change, meaning that tables created before this change would *never* support appending to in the future. 

It's better to defer fixing appends for new uploads one more release, rather than making it so that we will never be able to append to these older tables.
author: crisptrutski
comments_list: [{'comment_id': 2197195115, 'issue_id': 2380680843, 'author': 'crisptrutski', 'body': 'We don\'t need this anymore, as instead we "rolled forward" with https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/44873', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 6, 28, 15, 37, 46, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}]
comment_thread: crisptrutski (Issue Creator) on (2024-06-28 15:37:46 UTC): We don't need this anymore, as instead we "rolled forward" with https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/44873

title: Remove `:foreign-keys` feature or convert to `:metadata/key-constraints` where appropriate
body:
Closes  #44511 
Closes #44573
Closes #44842
Closes #45381
Closes #45589

### Description

This PR does multiple things:

1. Adds join alias also to Mongo lvalue fields. This is necessary for eg. sorting on joined fields to work correctly.
2. Changes implicit joins dependency from `:foreign-keys` to `:left-join`. That enables use of implicit joins with dbmses that do not support foreign keys.
3. Adds `add-foreign-keys!` function to `get-or-create` logic. That's responsible for adding foreign key relationships to app db manually for dbmses that do not support fks. This enables testing implicit joins.
4. As per [slack discussion](https://metaboat.slack.com/archives/C04DN5VRQM6/p1720024835058369?thread_ts=1719971343.726209&cid=C04DN5VRQM6), **this PR also removes `:foreign-keys` feature or converts usage to `:metadata/key-constraints`.**
5. Adds `escape-alias` implementation to presto.
6. Sets `:metadata/key-constraints` to false for bigquery.
7. Fixes bigquery's order by joined field functionality.
8. Sets sqlite :metadata/key-constraints to false.
9. Updates tests -- lot of tests that were depending on foreign keys now depend on `:left-join`. Meaning also eg. remapping tests run now with non `:metadata/key-constraints` drivers.
10. Sparks joy.

### How to verify

Run modified tests. Attempt reproduction from original issue.

### Checklist

- [X] Tests have been added/updated to cover changes in this PR
author: lbrdnk
labels: [('no-backport', 'Do not backport this PR to any branch')]

title: POC: import specs instead of creating one big spec file
body:
This is a POC to split up the e2e tests (again ü§ê) to but keep the performance benefits from using large consolidated spec files that have a lot of tests in them.

Writing smaller spec files is more pleasant for devs, but it has a downside: Cypress has to some setup for each spec file it encounters and all of the setup for all the small spec files adds up (consolidating the reproductions into one file, or a small set of files shaved 4m of a 15m CI run).

The (_unproved_) assumption of this POC is that if we write our tests in non-spec files (ie. Cypress doesn't think they are tests), but import all these small files into one large spec, we can have the best of both worlds:
- Cypress only picks up a couple of specs, so has to do less setup, resulting in better test performance
- Devs can write tests in small files instead of huge specs

This PR tests these assumptions by splitting up the question reproductions into a bunch of smaller test files again to see if the performance improvements are maintained.

If this works, in the future we could do more improvements.

1. import _all_ specs into one (or a low number) of large spec file so we completely eliminate any setup done by Cypress
2. Use different greps in CI and local dev for what the specs are so devs can run the small test files locally, but Cypress does not pick up on them in CI.


The question reproductions run [took 12m18s](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/actions/runs/9722494339/job/26836566677?pr=44889) on this PR vs. [12m24s on master](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/actions/runs/9720931022/job/26833122551), so it does not seem to impact performance.
author: romeovs
labels: [('.CI & Tests', ''), ('no-backport', 'Do not backport this PR to any branch'), ('.Team/Querying', ''), ('.Team/DevEx', '')]

title: replace html2cavas with html2canvas-pro to support color css functions
body:
### Description

While working on adding the pdf download functionality to public/embedded dashboard, I started running into this error after a rebase on master:
```
html2canvas.js:1726 Uncaught (in promise) Error: Attempting to parse an unsupported color function "color"
    at Object.parse (html2canvas.js:1726:1)
    at parse (html2canvas.js:3750:1)
    at new CSSParsedDeclaration (html2canvas.js:3644:1)
    at new ElementContainer (html2canvas.js:3796:1)
    at createContainer (html2canvas.js:4793:1)
    at parseNodeTree (html2canvas.js:4739:1)
    at parseTree (html2canvas.js:4798:1)
    at html2canvas.js:7783:1
    at step (html2canvas.js:86:1)
    at Object.next (html2canvas.js:67:1)
```
Trying to debug it, it seems like the library doesn't support some color functions like `srgb` `sgba` etc that we started to use.

You can reproduce it on [this branch](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/44463) by going to a public dashboard and trying to export it as pdf.

The original `html2canvas` has not been updated in two years: https://www.npmjs.com/package/html2canvas

The solution on [this issues](https://github.com/niklasvh/html2canvas/issues/2700) seems to be moving to [html2canvas-pro](https://www.npmjs.com/package/html2canvas-pro) which is a more maintained fork that supports the `color` function(s?).


### How to verify

Everything should work as before.
author: npretto
labels: [('no-backport', 'Do not backport this PR to any branch'), ('.Team/Embedding', '')]

title: Fix unable to rollback due to dropped not null constraint on 50
body:
Partially fixes https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/44784#issuecomment-2194903570

The case where you migrate to 50 and use it for a while. You'll start having `task_history.eneded_at = null ` in your db.

Now you want to rollback; you can't because rollback is trying to add a not null constraint on `task_history.ended_at, task_history.duration`, in which you have null values.

It's ok to not add these back because these values are not really used for anything other than showing it in the Admin/Troubleshooting/Tasks page.

Other checks:
- adding a rollback does not change the checksum
- drop not null is idempotence, so it won't fail when users try to upgrade again.
author: qnkhuat
labels: [('backport', 'Automatically create PR on current release branch on merge'), ('.Team/Workflows', 'aka BEC')]

title: Patch storybook to fix failed loki tests with runtime error
body:
We [encountered failed Loki tests](https://metaboat.slack.com/archives/C064QMXEV9N/p1719420501728319) when a story throw runtime errors.

This problem [is fixed in Storybook v7](https://github.com/storybookjs/storybook/commit/5d86bcfc9ad26595663ebdea7f6cc21b7943377e) but it [isn't easy to upgrade](https://metaboat.slack.com/archives/C064QMXEV9N/p1719428500883389?thread_ts=1719420501.728319&cid=C064QMXEV9N). So we resort to patching this instead for the time-being.

#### How to test
1. Before: Try to create a story with a runtime error. I think throwing some errors should do and run `yarn test-visual:loki` You should see loki failing when our story was trying to call `/runtime-error` endpoint.
2. After: run `yarn` to apply the patch and try running the test again.
author: WiNloSt
labels: [('backport', 'Automatically create PR on current release branch on merge'), ('.Team/Embedding', '')]

title: Rather support old files, than duplicate columns
body:
### Description

Resolves the call-out in https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/44727#issuecomment-2192717280

As it stands we have fixed the related P2, but turned it into somewhat of a P3 as the user will need to re-upload any existing file in order to append to their data. This work-around is also not discoverable.

We will want to get this merged before 50.8, otherwise we'll be breaking existing tables either way.

title: Allow defective duplicate fields
body:
This PR implements the changes in steps 1 and 2 from [this comment](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/44659#issuecomment-2192932023):

> 1. Create a migration to add a new boolean column is_defective_duplicate and mark the defective fields.
> 2. Expand the unique constraint on metabase_field to allow inactive defective duplicate fields to co-exist with the actual active fields of the same name, i.e. a unique constraint on (name, parent_id, table_id, is_defective_duplicate). Also update toucan select hooks to dissoc is_defective_duplicate. After this point, load-from-h2 works again.

It unblocks `load-from-h2` from the problem described in https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/44659, which will downgrade the issue from P1 to P2.

**Important background:**

- On all db types, we have a unique index on `metabase_field(table_id, parent_id, name)`. But most fields have `parent_id = null` (this column is only used for nested fields on MongoDB). In most databases, `NULL != NULL`, so that‚Äôs why you can have multiple a field with the same `(table_id, name)` and not violate the unique index.
- On Postgres, we made tighter constraints around duplicates because it supports partial index and we added a unique index on `(table_id, name) where parent_id is null`. This is why `load-from-h2` only fails when you migrate to Postgres.

Related: 
- [Slack discussion about how this is blocking load-from-h2.](https://metaboat.slack.com/archives/C013VC33N95/p1718877409134089?thread_ts=1718814222.803569&cid=C013VC33N95)
- [Slack thread started by Ngoc on the solution](https://metaboat.slack.com/archives/C0641E4PB9B/p1719380668675549)
- [Original issue that was closed when the root cause was fixed](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/44459)

### To verify:
1. Start Metabase from https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/43812 with `git checkout 33df115`. Use MB with a fresh H2 app DB.
3. Create a Postgres DB with this table
```
DROP DATABASE IF EXISTS test_db; 
CREATE DATABASE test_db;

CREATE TABLE my_table (
    id serial PRIMARY KEY,
    data jsonb
);

INSERT INTO my_table (data)
VALUES ('[1, 2, 3]'::jsonb);
```
4. Sync the created DB. 
5. Verify that defective duplicate fields exist by trying to create a question that selects two "Data" fields from `my_table`.
6. Execute the `load-from-h2` command to migrate the app DB from H2 to Postgres:
```
export MB_DB_TYPE=postgres
export MB_DB_CONNECTION_URI="jdbc:postgresql://<host>:5432/metabase?user=<username>&password=<password>"
clojure -M:run load-from-h2 /path/to/metabase.db
```
It should not succeed.
7. Checkout this branch and try step 6 again. It should succeed this time.
8. Start Metabase again using the newly migrated Postgres app DB.
```
export MB_DB_TYPE=postgres
export MB_DB_CONNECTION_URI="jdbc:postgresql://<host>:5432/metabase?user=<username>&password=<password>"
clojure -M:dev
```
author: calherries
labels: [('backport', 'Automatically create PR on current release branch on merge'), ('.Team/Workflows', 'aka BEC')]
comments_list:
[{'comment_id': 2196108211, 'issue_id': 2379529268, 'author': 'replay-io[bot]', 'body': '

Status Complete ‚ÜóÔ∏é
Commit 01f6a4eafa0acb00dbd3dcea95d07507f7566698
Results
‚ö†Ô∏è 3 Flaky
‚úÖ 2763 Passed
', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 6, 28, 4, 22, 42, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2204969118, 'issue_id': 2379529268, 'author': 'qnkhuat', 'body': "Is there a good reason we need to have this migration on 49? AFAIK, we have had this problem for a long time now, so it's not something we introduced in 49; the #43812 PR just makes it easier to hit. I'd prefer to have this on 50. 49 should be stable now, and we don't want to introduce possible failure for patch updates.", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 3, 2, 53, 50, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2205011493, 'issue_id': 2379529268, 'author': 'qnkhuat', 'body': 'I think this works but it introduces some problems: 1. postgres and MySQL unique indexes are different on postgres ``` "idx_uniq_field_table_id_parent_id_name" UNIQUE CONSTRAINT, btree (table_id, parent_id, name) "idx_uniq_field_table_id_parent_id_name_2col" UNIQUE, btree (table_id, name) WHERE parent_id IS NULL AND is_defective_duplicate = false ``` on MySQL ``` UNIQUE KEY `idx_unique_field` (`name`,`table_id`,`unique_field_helper`), ``` 2. unique_field_helper is just a dummy column on postgres, wheares on MySQL and h2 it's a generated column. I think we can and should reduce the asymmetry between Postgres and MySQL, H2. Especially when it's why we have this bug in the first place. I got an idea and I think it'll work: - we drop all existing unique indexes on metabase_field - create a column `defective_duplicate_count`, this column has a default value of 0 and can't be updated by the appDB. - create a migration for MySQL and H2 that fill `defective_duplicate_count` with value is the row_number() of the duplicated fields. - Create a generated column `unique_identifier generated always as (table_id || '_' || COALESCE(parent_id::TEXT, 'null') || '_' || name || '_' || defective_duplicate_count );` - Create a unique index on `unique_identifier` This will allow duplicate fields to co-exist because it has `defective_duplicate_count > 0`. And since `defective_duplicate_count` has a default of 0 and can't be updated by appDB, it'll also prevent us from adding duplicate fields. Another nice thing about this is that we have the same index and generated column across dbms.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 3, 3, 34, 43, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2205131077, 'issue_id': 2379529268, 'author': 'calherries', 'body': "That's a nice idea to achieve consistency. It's equivalent to extending `v49.2024-06-27T00:00:07` and `v49.2024-06-27T00:00:08` to Postgres. I considered it but the approach I have now intentionally avoids having to introduce the generated column for Postgres, at the cost of some consistency. I'm open to it but not sure the consistency is worth it. Skipping a generated column (probably?) performs better", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 3, 5, 31, 1, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2205134749, 'issue_id': 2379529268, 'author': 'calherries', 'body': '> Is there a good reason we need to have this migration on 49? #43812 was backported to 49 and released in 49.15', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 3, 5, 35, 4, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2206245400, 'issue_id': 2379529268, 'author': 'qnkhuat', 'body': "> intentionally avoids having to introduce the generated column for Postgres why? if it's about performance then I don't think it matter much here because field is not frequently updated. > but not sure the consistency is worth it IMO, it is. I think we have more than enough difference between MySQL and Postgres already(I just discovered this [one](https://metaboat.slack.com/archives/C0641E4PB9B/p1720015474515889)); we shouldn't have more if we can avoid it.", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 3, 14, 17, 7, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2206935369, 'issue_id': 2379529268, 'author': 'calherries', 'body': "After sleeping on this, I'm persuaded consistency across DBs is worth any tiny perf hits we get from adding the generated column. I'll make them consistent. Rather than concatenate strings as you suggested, I think it's sufficient to extend my current approach for H2 and MySQL to Postgres. It's both less effort and the resulting index and table will be smaller.", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 3, 18, 16, 22, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2207382539, 'issue_id': 2379529268, 'author': 'calherries', 'body': "I made a controversial change that's worth pointing out. When this PR's changesets are rolled back, we don't restore the `idx_uniq_field_table_id_parent_id_name_2col` unique index for Postgres app DBs. That's the constraint that prevents defective duplicates from existing in Postgres: https://github.com/metabase/metabase/blob/f45dd8891c02ddb7a332362d0e988fd6f9c85c56/resources/migrations/000_legacy_migrations.yaml#L5684-L5692 We need to remove the constraint because otherwise you couldn't migrate from H2/MySQL to Postgres with load-from-h2 and then subsequently downgrade to 48. And we also roll back the `idx_unique_field` constraint that is added on upgrade. That means that if you upgrade to 49, then downgrade to 48 with a Postgres app DB, the app DB will have weaker constraints than before. Instead of both `idx_uniq_field_table_id_parent_id_name_2col` and `idx_uniq_field_table_id_parent_id_name`, a Postgres app DB will only have `idx_uniq_field_table_id_parent_id_name`, like MySQL and H2.", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 3, 21, 59, 47, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2211540577, 'issue_id': 2379529268, 'author': 'calherries', 'body': '@metabase-bot backport release-x.49.x', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 6, 0, 34, 1, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 2211541052, 'issue_id': 2379529268, 'author': 'github-actions[bot]', 'body': '@calherries something went wrong while creating a backport [[Logs]](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/actions/runs/9815071479)', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 6, 0, 35, 4, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}]

Status Complete ‚ÜóÔ∏é
Commit 01f6a4eafa0acb00dbd3dcea95d07507f7566698
Results
‚ö†Ô∏è 3 Flaky
‚úÖ 2763 Passed
qnkhuat on (2024-07-03 02:53:50 UTC): Is there a good reason we need to have this migration on 49? AFAIK, we have had this problem for a long time now, so it's not something we introduced in 49; the #43812 PR just makes it easier to hit. I'd prefer to have this on 50. 49 should be stable now, and we don't want to introduce possible failure for patch updates. qnkhuat on (2024-07-03 03:34:43 UTC): I think this works but it introduces some problems: 1. postgres and MySQL unique indexes are different on postgres ``` "idx_uniq_field_table_id_parent_id_name" UNIQUE CONSTRAINT, btree (table_id, parent_id, name) "idx_uniq_field_table_id_parent_id_name_2col" UNIQUE, btree (table_id, name) WHERE parent_id IS NULL AND is_defective_duplicate = false ``` on MySQL ``` UNIQUE KEY `idx_unique_field` (`name`,`table_id`,`unique_field_helper`), ``` 2. unique_field_helper is just a dummy column on postgres, wheares on MySQL and h2 it's a generated column. I think we can and should reduce the asymmetry between Postgres and MySQL, H2. Especially when it's why we have this bug in the first place. I got an idea and I think it'll work: - we drop all existing unique indexes on metabase_field - create a column `defective_duplicate_count`, this column has a default value of 0 and can't be updated by the appDB. - create a migration for MySQL and H2 that fill `defective_duplicate_count` with value is the row_number() of the duplicated fields. - Create a generated column `unique_identifier generated always as (table_id || '_' || COALESCE(parent_id::TEXT, 'null') || '_' || name || '_' || defective_duplicate_count );` - Create a unique index on `unique_identifier` This will allow duplicate fields to co-exist because it has `defective_duplicate_count > 0`. And since `defective_duplicate_count` has a default of 0 and can't be updated by appDB, it'll also prevent us from adding duplicate fields. Another nice thing about this is that we have the same index and generated column across dbms. calherries (Issue Creator) on (2024-07-03 05:31:01 UTC): That's a nice idea to achieve consistency. It's equivalent to extending `v49.2024-06-27T00:00:07` and `v49.2024-06-27T00:00:08` to Postgres. I considered it but the approach I have now intentionally avoids having to introduce the generated column for Postgres, at the cost of some consistency. I'm open to it but not sure the consistency is worth it. Skipping a generated column (probably?) performs better calherries (Issue Creator) on (2024-07-03 05:35:04 UTC): #43812 was backported to 49 and released in 49.15 qnkhuat on (2024-07-03 14:17:07 UTC): why? if it's about performance then I don't think it matter much here because field is not frequently updated. IMO, it is. I think we have more than enough difference between MySQL and Postgres already(I just discovered this [one](https://metaboat.slack.com/archives/C0641E4PB9B/p1720015474515889)); we shouldn't have more if we can avoid it. calherries (Issue Creator) on (2024-07-03 18:16:22 UTC): After sleeping on this, I'm persuaded consistency across DBs is worth any tiny perf hits we get from adding the generated column. I'll make them consistent. Rather than concatenate strings as you suggested, I think it's sufficient to extend my current approach for H2 and MySQL to Postgres. It's both less effort and the resulting index and table will be smaller. calherries (Issue Creator) on (2024-07-03 21:59:47 UTC): I made a controversial change that's worth pointing out. When this PR's changesets are rolled back, we don't restore the `idx_uniq_field_table_id_parent_id_name_2col` unique index for Postgres app DBs. That's the constraint that prevents defective duplicates from existing in Postgres: https://github.com/metabase/metabase/blob/f45dd8891c02ddb7a332362d0e988fd6f9c85c56/resources/migrations/000_legacy_migrations.yaml#L5684-L5692 We need to remove the constraint because otherwise you couldn't migrate from H2/MySQL to Postgres with load-from-h2 and then subsequently downgrade to 48. And we also roll back the `idx_unique_field` constraint that is added on upgrade. That means that if you upgrade to 49, then downgrade to 48 with a Postgres app DB, the app DB will have weaker constraints than before. Instead of both `idx_uniq_field_table_id_parent_id_name_2col` and `idx_uniq_field_table_id_parent_id_name`, a Postgres app DB will only have `idx_uniq_field_table_id_parent_id_name`, like MySQL and H2. calherries (Issue Creator) on (2024-07-06 00:34:01 UTC): @metabase-bot backport release-x.49.x github-actions[bot] on (2024-07-06 00:35:04 UTC): @calherries something went wrong while creating a backport [[Logs]](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/actions/runs/9815071479)

title: fix: limit xrays on agg models to source fields
body:
Fixes #43793

1. `table-like?` was checking aggregations but not breakouts. This meant that legacy metric definitions would try to apply to the second stage which is generally illegal and would cause things like implicit joins to come in where they make no sense.
2. Trying to bin a `count` metric-like model would give a bin span of 0.0 which would blow up those questions.
3. Trying to self reference breakout fields, in the precense of a question's  aggregation meant that most fields would not be exposed to the next stage and should be ignored. (similar to 1.)
author: snoe
labels: [('backport', 'Automatically create PR on current release branch on merge')]

title: Better display names for CSV upload tables
body:
This PR does two things:
1. Improves the display name for CSV upload tables to be more user-friendly.
2. Truncates the table's display name and name and the model's name to the maximum size the app DB allows, which allowing files with long names to be uploaded.*

*If the filename exceeds the filesystem's limits (e.g. 255 bytes for UNIX), the upload will still fail. But that's out of scope.

### **Previously** 

The display name for a table was just the humanized version of the table name. The table name is the concatenation of the upload table name prefix, the slugified file name, and a unique timestamp.

That results in ugly table names like this:

![image](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/assets/39073188/0137cca4-3b30-465c-83cf-61b4ed6742bc)

It's worse for non-ASCII characters; for a CSV file called °®∏Êº¢.csv the name of the table would be `<upload-prefix>%3F%3F%E6%BC%A2_<timestamp>` and the display name would be the humanized version of that: `<upload-prefix>%3F%3F%E6%BC%A2 <timestamp>`.

### **After this PR**

We'll set the display name from newly uploaded tables to directly from the file name, rather than from the name of the table.

So the display name for a file called "°®∏Êº¢.csv" would be "°®∏Êº¢". We'll also humanize the file name, so the display name for a file called "some_FILE-name.csv" would be "Some File Name".

For any files with really long names that result in a display name that exceeds the size of the `display_name` field in the app DB, we'll truncate the string to the maximum size for the field. The same truncation applies to the `report_card.name` field for the upload model.
author: calherries
labels: [('backport', 'Automatically create PR on current release branch on merge'), ('.Team/Workflows', 'aka BEC')]

title: improve cartesian charts performance
body: Closes https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/44778 ### Description Improves slow cartesian charts rendering on larger datasets by reducing number of expensive operations that include: - call cljs metabase-lib code - format text - measure text width **1) Optimize `scaleDataset`** It [used to call](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/44861/files#diff-ad0928481b30ef8299f367e9bb5f751f4e4750709c3006d7809c979105240a6eL639) `getColumnScaling` per series per datum but this function inside calls `getColumnKey` which calls cljs metabase-lib code that turned out to be not so fast. **2) Optimize `aggregateColumnValuesForDatum`** It [used to call](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/44861/files#diff-ad0928481b30ef8299f367e9bb5f751f4e4750709c3006d7809c979105240a6eL126) `isMetric` metabase-lib function per datum per series which also turned out to be expensive. **3) Optimize `getTicksDimensions`** Previously, we [computed the width of every x-axis tick](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/44861/files#diff-da82c365b720de7b1763897dad5f4317e53823954e8f7cdabfd01166e59a32d3L315) which involves formatting and measuring text width. Both operations are expensive and it does not make much sense to call it for every tick on 10k length datasets. Now for continuous values such as numbers or dates we measure 50 values from the dataset including start and end. On category values we select top 50 values by string length and measure them. ### How to verify CI is green: nothing should change in terms of charts behavior. Compare how charts with many data points behave compared in terms of performance with `master`. ### Demo 20k data points **Before** First `useModelAndOption` took 1.86s Subsequent call ~760 ms **After** First `useModelAndOption` took 574ms Subsequent call ~16 ms ### Checklist - [n/a] Tests have been added/updated to cover changes in this PR

title: Ensure we close the canceled chan in query processor after query
body:
Customer complaints that thread growth was unbounded. Investigated and found bigquery involved and isolated to the cancel thread bits. Gist is this:

```clojure
      (when cancel-chan
        (future                       ; this needs to run in a separate thread, because the <!! operation blocks forever
          (when (a/<!! cancel-chan)
            (log/debug "Received a message on the cancel channel; attempting to stop the BigQuery query execution")
            (reset! cancel-requested? true) ; signal the page iteration fn to stop
            (if-not (or (future-cancelled? res-fut) (future-done? res-fut))
              ;; somehow, even the FIRST page hasn't come back yet (i.e. the .query call above), so cancel the future to
              ;; interrupt the thread waiting on that response to come back
              ;; unfortunately, with this particular overload of .query, we have no access to (nor the ability to control)
              ;; the jobId, so we have no way to use the BigQuery client to cancel any job that might be running
              (future-cancel res-fut)
              (when (future-done? res-fut) ; canceled received after it was finished; may as well return it
                @res-fut)))))
```

The important parts is that we closeover the cancel-chan and start a thread that is trying to pull from it. If we never put anything on that channel or never close that channel this thread will just remain blocked waiting.

In a thread dump, that looks like the following:
(note, I've made it set the thread names to make it easy to follow run a query 30 times)

```
   java.lang.Thread.State: WAITING (parking)
	at jdk.internal.misc.Unsafe.park(java.base@21.0.2/Native Method)

```

Simple repro:

```clojure
bigquery-profile=> (require '[clojure.core.async :as a])
nil
bigquery-profile=> (let [c (a/chan)
                         t (Thread. (fn []
                                      (when (a/<!! c)
                                        (println "got something")))
                                    "Forever-running")]
                     (.start t)
                     (a/close! c)
                     (Thread/sleep 4000)
                     (let [thread-names (into #{} (map ^[] Thread/.getName) (.keySet (Thread/getAllStackTraces)))]
                       (contains? thread-names "Forever-running")))
false
bigquery-profile=> (let [c (a/chan)
                         t (Thread. (fn []
                                      (when (a/<!! c)
                                        (println "got something")))
                                    "Forever-running")]
                     (.start t)
                     #_(a/close! c) ;; if we don't close it will never stop running
                     (Thread/sleep 4000)
                     (let [thread-names (into #{} (map ^[] Thread/.getName) (.keySet (Thread/getAllStackTraces)))]
                       (contains? thread-names "Forever-running")))
true
```

So this PR just adds a transducer around the rf that closes the `cancel-chan` if it's open. Note that multiple closes are fine: from the docstring: "Closing a closed channel is a no-op".
author: dpsutton
labels: [('backport', 'Automatically create PR on current release branch on merge')]

title: Support specific date filters with 00:00 time
body: Fixes https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/43057 Previously we didn't differentiate between date and date + 00:00 time filters on the FE, so 00:00 got converted to the whole date. This leads to different query results. This PR fixes the issue and moves `hasTime` from UI state to `filterParts` and computes it based on the serialized date format. This matches how QP and MBQL lib work. How to verify: - Open Orders - Add filter for Created At - `On`, `November 18, 2024` - Try it with and without 00:00 time - Your choice should be preserved and you should get different query results.
author: ranquild
labels: [('backport', 'Automatically create PR on current release branch on merge'), ('.Team/Querying', '')]

title: Fix pin maps unnecessarily filtering out null values
body:
- Closes: https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/34775
---
**Demo**


https://github.com/metabase/metabase/assets/22608765/9379e0b5-6c92-4f10-a625-7468f01f37a1



---
**Acceptance Criteria**
- [ ] Pin maps no longer filter out rows with null values in a non-coordinate column (lat and long cannot be null, but the other values in the row can be)
- [ ] Unit test added to validate and enforce the desired behavior
- [ ] All other behaviors are the same
- [ ] All other tests continue to pass

title: backported "Error on import into an empty appdb (#44840)"
body:
Backports #44840 

I was thinking about the potential options here.

On one hand, we could initialize the app db ourselves. This is a little problematic, because:

- our `init!` function is in `metabase.core` and calling it yields a painful cyclical dependency. It's also pretty tied to outputting things to the user that they might not expect during an import, e.g. "Looks like this is a new installation ... preparing setup wizard", and starts up jobs, etc.

- if we choose to *only* initialize the database ourselves (only the bits that we actually *need* initialized), I'm a little nervous about maybe missing something. Right now we need to create the internal user and create users from the config file before running the import. If we added a third thing, would we remember to update this?

- we could refactor to put all of the above in one spot, but this is a P1 and it feels important to close this out as quickly as possible. We also don't claim to support initializing the app DB from an import in the first place.

So: just throw an exception if the app db hasn't been set up yet. Our heuristic here is whether a single non-internal user has been created. So if you want to use your config, you can run:

```
MB_CONFIG_FILE_PATH=dev/config.yml java -jar metabase.jar
java -jar metabase.jar import /my/exported/dump
```

If you try to run `java -jar metabase.jar import ...` on a fresh DB, it'll now fail with the error message:

```
You cannot `import` into an empty database. Please set up Metabase
normally, then retry.
```
author: johnswanson
labels: [('.Team/AdminWebapp', 'Admin and Webapp team')]

title: Error on import into an empty appdb
body:
I was thinking about the potential options here.

On one hand, we could initialize the app db ourselves. This is a little problematic, because:

- our `init!` function is in `metabase.core` and calling it yields a painful cyclical dependency. It's also pretty tied to outputting things to the user that they might not expect during an import, e.g. "Looks like this is a new installation ... preparing setup wizard", and starts up jobs, etc.

- if we choose to *only* initialize the database ourselves (only the bits that we actually *need* initialized), I'm a little nervous about maybe missing something. Right now we need to create the internal user and create users from the config file before running the import. If we added a third thing, would we remember to update this?

- we could refactor to put all of the above in one spot, but this is a P1 and it feels important to close this out as quickly as possible. We also don't claim to support initializing the app DB from an import in the first place.

So: just throw an exception if the app db hasn't been set up yet. Our heuristic here is whether a single non-internal user has been created. So if you want to use your config, you can run:

```
MB_CONFIG_FILE_PATH=dev/config.yml java -jar metabase.jar
java -jar metabase.jar import /my/exported/dump
```

If you try to run `java -jar metabase.jar import ...` on a fresh DB, it'll now fail with the error message:

```
You cannot `import` into an empty database. Please set up Metabase
normally, then retry.
```

Fixes #44739
author: johnswanson
labels: [('backport', 'Automatically create PR on current release branch on merge'), ('.Team/AdminWebapp', 'Admin and Webapp team')]

title: Parse not a number passed to id filter
body:
Closes https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/44790

### Description

If a string passed as a value to query param, it is treated as a valid value, but parsing it as a number causes convertion to NaN and passing it to mbql, which hangs

### How to verify

you need to have a dashboard with id filter and the value passed to it like `{{param}}` via URL parameter

### Demo


https://github.com/metabase/metabase/assets/125459446/b312604d-db18-435b-99f7-8531c69adfff



### Checklist

- tests will be added in a separate PR
author: uladzimirdev
labels: [('backport', 'Automatically create PR on current release branch on merge'), ('.Team/Querying', '')]

title: Be explicit about truncating characters versus bytes
body:
### Description

We pun on bytes and characters when dealing with determining the table and field names for uploads, because we are always dealing with ASCII characters.

Despite things being OK for now, future code unaware of this gotcha could re-use these driver methods with strings containing multi-byte codepoints, or conversely we could change the way that we normalize table names and no longer use ASCII. The probability is not high, but there's no harm in being more precise in our comments, and declaring our assumptions

Thanks to [this call out](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/44727#discussion_r1655478906) for spurring this change.
author: crisptrutski
labels: [('backport', 'Automatically create PR on current release branch on merge'), ('.Team/Workflows', 'aka BEC')]

title: Fix appending to existing tables with truncated column names
body:
### Description

This fixes an issue where uploads created using a previous version of Metabase could not be appended to, even with newer versions.

See https://github.com/metabase/metabase/pull/44727#issuecomment-2192717280 for a good explanation of this bug.

If we had already released the related PR, we'd have been unable to support appends to both older and newer tables, so it's lucky that we caught this quickly.
author: crisptrutski
labels: [('backport', 'Automatically create PR on current release branch on merge'), ('.Team/Workflows', 'aka BEC')]

title: Reproduction for "When List style field is changed to show remapped foreign key, then cached values are not updated"
body:
Closes https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/15542


The issue was fixed in v50, and this PR adds a reproduction for it.

The test in this PR is a bit messy: for it to reproduce the actual issue it needs to navigate to different pages within the SPA **without doing a full page reload** to avoid clearing the cache. The test therefore cannot make use of the usual `openOrdersTable`-style helpers in clicks around the UI to do the navigation instead.

[Stress test](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/actions/runs/9694628954/job/26752669166)

title: Performance: partial data-permissions graph refactor
body:
Closes #44768

### Description

Updates to the BE (code already approved) and FE changes to allow for partial editing of permissions graphs in the admin settings. This change detects which groups have had some kind of modification within the graph and only sends that part of the graph / omits unmodified groups in the update request body. The backend now only sends a response with just the modified groups, which the FE will now merge back into the client's graph.

### How to verify

The changes _should_ not change the user experience in any way than increasing performance. Please verify that modifying permissions continue to do what you'd expect.

### Checklist

- [x] Tests have been added/updated to cover changes in this PR

title: Single Log Out saml-slo-enabled defsetting
body:
resolves #44758

This adds a `defsetting` called `saml-slo-enabled` in the sso-settings namespace.

It defaults to false, and if it's false then we won't do the single logout flow, as requested in #44758.

This is going to be a breaking change, for users who rely on us doing SLO when logging out, so that needs to be in the changelog.

title: Fix n+1 query in sandboxing enforcement
body:
Resolves https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/44786

In order to check whether a sandbox should be enforced for a user we need to check that no _other_ group the user is in provides access. This previously ended up as an n+1 query: for each sandbox we were hitting the DB individually for each other sandbox.

I've changed this to be a single query per sandbox, which takes a set of the groups to check and fetches all their permissions at once. I've had to restructure the logic a little, but the behavior should be the same.

title: Remove `large-int-id` String serialization middleware [DO NOT MERGE YET]
body:
Part of the fix for #5816

Since JS stores all numbers as 64-bit doubles by default it can't parse integer literals larger than `9007199254740991` in JSON query results. As a hack we serialized those numbers to strings. Going forward we'll just tweak our JSON parser to parse them to `BigInt`s instead. 

This PR removes the icky middleware that serialized large integers to strings. The main goal here is to see if any backend tests break and need to be updated, or if we have e2e tests around this stuff 

See Slack discussion https://metaboat.slack.com/archives/C04DN5VRQM6/p1719433869236109
author: camsaul
